There is only one person who can prop up the co-ops and that is the producer. It is the fella milking the cows this morning and this evening. He is the only person that you take the money off. The same applies to the cattle going into the factory. The producer props this up. I will give my opinion and then I will get to my questions. When things are good, everything goes up. We can see this with the price of diesel, insurance, oil and everything else. Everything goes up but when they drop, they do not drop proportionally with it either and we are left then carrying the can, and we are in a minus situation. People do not even believe that. My father before me did it and I have been a dairy farmer all of my life. To produce winter milk at the moment is not going to pay going forward because of the costs. How long can somebody sustain that? We do it and I compare myself with the shopkeepers years ago when I was a young fella, delivering milk in Portlaoise. Where are all the small shops gone? They are all closed. They loved meeting the people but they just could not keep the doors open. Then the younger generation came along and decided to close a lot of these businesses down. It was hard on families but they were not making money, so they closed them. Other people kept going because of their pride. Pride keeps us going but when it comes to the next generation they look at a non-profitable business and close the doors.

Leaving all of that aside, we have one hope and that is all of us going together. We are all farmers, at the end of the day and we are all producing stuff out of the ground as best we can and we have excelled ourselves in many areas. As was said, it does not matter if it is horses or not, we are just brilliant at what we do and we have very good veins of land in the country, some better than others, and we have to look after the person in order that we all get an income out of it.

Going back to the CAP, my questions are, what changes to environmental measures, eco-schemes, conditionality, stock limits and biodiversity actions are needed to deliver workable climate and nature outcomes without undermining farm incomes or livestock production? What role should co-operatives and producer organisations play in improving market power, pricing transparency and fairness to the supply chain, and what CAP instruments could strengthen this role for us? We spoke earlier about simplification measures and everybody is in line with me on it. Under CAP, going forward, what specific simplification measures, in inspections, paperwork, compliance, digital systems or scheme eligibility rules are most urgently needed to reduce the administrative burden for farmers in the next CAP budget? I would like to hear answers from the witnesses to these questions.
I was going to answer Deputy Fitzmaurice's question first, but I do not want to take away from Deputy Aird.
That is okay, we are all here together.
We will get them all answered.

On what effect the reduction in livestock numbers would have for ICOS co-ops, the main concern would be the decrease in farmers with it. The two of them contribute particularly to a decline in business and use for co-op agriculture trading stores and that is not just bad for the co-op, that is also bad for the farmers they serve. Many of them are in remote areas and many of those farm businesses depend on that store for their inputs and ultimately that could be an issue.

My colleagues have spoken well about the importance of generational renewal. The price of animals and the demand for animals is probably something of a barrier for entry for the next cohort of farmers coming in. The price for animals has been a due reward for people who stuck at it, so we are certainly not saying that it should decrease, but that is where we see it with the decline in livestock.
To Deputy Aird, the co-ops do inherently play that role in giving farmers a stronger place in the marketplace and a better bargaining position.

With regard to what CAP can do, it should maintain its fully funded budget and ring-fenced nature in respect of both Pillar 1 and Pillar 2, providing stability so that, like farmers, co-ops can make investments, develop products and markets, and negotiate on behalf of farmers. That stability is good for the farmer and the co-op alike. I do not know if Mr. Enright has anything to add but that is all I have.

On Deputy Aird's question on the changes that need to be made to environmental measures under the CAP, the dairy vision report, the beef vision report and the tillage vision report all looked at the climate issue. From where we stand, they seem to be gathering dust. We also have the just transition and we now have the nature restoration law. CAP cannot do the job on these because the money is simply not there, even within the existing budget. If these issues are to be addressed, funding will have to come from elsewhere.

On simplification, we have been hearing about simplification for years. Our concern is that there seems to be a very strong focus on simplifying for the regulators while the focus on simplifying for the farmers is not as strong. We need to get down to simplifying issues for farmers. Our perspective is that we need to reform the schemes we have. We need to look at what is in the schemes and what is relevant. We also need to properly reward farmers for participation in those schemes. We are not properly rewarding farmers. Those are the two points I would make in relation to that.

I will speak to the environment question. The Deputy asked what changes need to be made to the environment measures. They need to start being realistic. We need a definitive start point. We talk about climate being global but the environment is local. Very often, we only talk about the impact farming has on a particular area and not about all of the co-contributing factors. You cannot just target farmers in isolation and expect the environment to magically spring back. As the majority landowners, farmers do have a huge impact but there are things upstream and downstream and surrounding them that also have impacts. All of that is completely ignored. We need precise and targeted measures implemented at local level rather than broad overarching things. We have some broad overarching things that actually disimprove the environment. Calendar farming is one example. Depending on the weather in any given year, are farmers empowered and supported to get slurry or muck spread at the appropriate time for their land, their needs and their nutrient values? The answer is that they are not. We need to think about it in a more realistic way and to stop bringing in broad overarching things.

We are living through a nightmare with these environmental issues. We have carbon footprints, emissions, methane and different levies on schemes and other things. These are all coming at us and payments are being cut, which hits us directly. No farmer has ever been given out a print-out or statement of what is on their farm, where reductions and changes can be made or how things could be improved. That is something we have been seeking for years. At the same time, it has happened even with the price of heating oil. It has happened with many different things. This is what we need to address. Give us a statement and let us work from there as we go forward.

I acknowledge Deputy Aird's comments about the dairy sector and how farmers are on more marginal land and harder ground. At last week's hearing, he talked about the Golden Vale versus the top of Kerry. We are all farming to the best of our ability, particularly in the areas I represent. It is not fully about production. There is now talk about environmental dividends and resilience to climate change. It has been clear to see in recent times that lands along the western seaboard have the ability to adapt to climate change. They are very resilient. There is more moisture in the soil and they can cater for times of drought. It is not unusual to see cattle going in when the ground is burnt up in the middle of the summertime. This may be a reality of climate change but that resilience is there. As the Deputy said, we all have to work together, whether we are at the top of Kerry or in the Golden Vale. We need to help each other out. It is critical that all farmers are defined equally in the regulation. As I said earlier, it is divisive. There is an opportunity here to pit two different types of farmers, those whose principal activity is an agricultural activity and those whose principal activity is not, against each other. We do not want to go down that road. I say that to all members of the committee. We need to keep all the people who are farming farming, whether they are on the top of a hill, in the Golden Vale or anywhere in between.
Part-time farmers are farming but cannot make a living at home, is that not it?

I am sorry that I was not here earlier on. On Questions on Policy or Legislation in the Dáil today, I asked Deputy Micheál Martin about what went on recently with the Mercosur meat that came over and the hormones that were detected in it. The CAP is there for food security. I basically asked whether cars are more important than public health. I got absolute waffle in response. I said that to the Taoiseach across the room. I told him he did not answer my questions. There was absolutely no answer. That tells you where the priorities lie. I guarantee that they do not lie with public health. The Government has its buddies in Europe with their big deals and fancy cars. That is what it all boils down to. It does not matter whether we are talking about derogations, the CAP budget or the Mercosur agreement; that is where the priorities are. The farming community is small but we feed everybody. I also asked the Taoiseach whether he was worried about this and told him that I was worried about the food I am giving my children. That is where all of this should be targeted. It should not be kept in-house within the farming community because it matters to everybody. It is about the mother feeding her child and the people in our nursing homes. It is about all of these people. The witnesses have spoken about other issues. Nobody has mentioned the public health bill we will face in years to come. Who is going to foot that bill? Who is going to pay for it when our health has gone downhill? I have said here in the committee that we should have sent people out to Brazil and the other Mercosur countries to see what is going on. We cannot take the word-----
To be helpful, we are arranging for a meeting on the Mercosur agreement but this meeting is focused on the CAP.

I am getting to my point. The CAP was designed for food security and health. It is all connected. Deputy Aird was talking about schemes. I guarantee that, if farmers had more input into schemes, they would be a lot simpler. I do not remember ever getting a survey at home asking how a scheme we had signed up to had worked. We were never asked for our input, what we felt we gained from the scheme or what was bad about it. We do surveys on everything else. Where are the surveys for the farmers? I have not done one. I do most of the paperwork for the farm at home and I have not filled one out. Schemes need to be designed around the farmer. There should be nothing about you without you.

Schemes that are designed from the top down are bound to fail. We must design everything from the bottom up, because without a bottom, the deck of cards will fall over. What input has there been by farming organisations into the existing schemes? That is the first question. Food security must be the way to go. The budget cannot be cut because it would have a big impact on our food security and food health. Food health is where the fight has to be.

We have four boys at home on the farm. I would love to say to one of them that he can have it. My husband knew early in his career that he was going to farm. It is a great life, but it is a hard life. As Mr. Donnelly said, if a cow is going to calve, it is going to calve. The idea of having a part-time job does not work so well for a suckler man. It is fine for us to be at home as we have young kids. My husband is at home and he is able to look after them as well as the farm, but a cow does not wait for anybody when she is calving. It is difficult for that end of it at a certain time of the year.

How can farming organisations have more input when it comes to the schemes? How can we demand that this cut is not going to happen? How do we speak to the wider community, outside the farming organisations, to explain that food health is at risk? I do not want to eat beef from another country where they can do what they like. With all the hoops that we have had to jump through because of Europe, farmers are proud of the food they produce. It is top quality. We have the best ground to produce top quality food. I will leave it to the witnesses to respond.

In terms of schemes, from an IBLA point of view, we would like to be invited to some of the stakeholder meetings. We are not included in the CAP stakeholder group, so we are not going to be asked for our opinion on what we should be doing with the CAP. For some reason we are out in the cold. We had our fifth AGM in November, yet we do not seem to be wanted. Perhaps our questions are too direct or we are asking questions that others are not asking. Our view is that we need to be in the room in a consultative process.

In terms of food security, one of the most important things is the label that goes on food, not just the food we might buy in the retail sector but also in the food service area. Let us look at the amount of food that comes into the country, including the couple of hundred tonnes of beef that comes into Europe from outside. Someone is eating that beef. Do we know what we are actually getting when we buy a product? What is the label on a sandwich that we buy in a corner shop? Is the country of origin clear? If, for whatever reason, Mercosur comes in, how are we going to know where the additional 99,000 tonnes of beef are going? Are consumers going to be able to make informed decisions? The retailer will not stock something that no one buys. If consumers are able to make informed decisions then they are able to say they do not want to eat that, therefore, they will not buy it and it will not be stocked. They are the answers to the Deputy's two questions.

To add to what Mr. Donnelly has said, equally, the Beef Plan Movement is not recognised. It is an interesting question the Deputy asks as to why that is the case or why the participation has not been sought, welcomed or requested. If I were a cynical person – whoops, oh dear, I am – I would wonder about the sectors that we represent, because the fact is that in 2003, Ireland, in its third contribution to the United Nations, made it very clear that the suckler industry in this country would bear the brunt of climate policies. That has proven to be the case. Our industry is declining because the policies that dictate it have said that it must. We must produce less beef, lighter animals and lighter cows. It is the suckler cow population that is affected, and dairy cows have recently begun to join us. The suckler cow population has been plummeting in recent years without any comment at all. Again, if I were a cynical person, why would I want me at the table to object to the decision that has already been taken on the destruction of my industry?

The ICSA is the only organisation that has a suckler committee. There is no point in denying it. The big problem with schemes is that we are not listened to. We come in here and debate with the different parties, the Department and the whole lot but we are not listened to. They just go and do their own thing afterwards. We saw that perfectly clearly with the suckler cow scheme where the ICBF and Bord Bia had to be brought in for us to draw down our money. A lot of farmers did not bother drawing it down because they did not want to be in the ICBF or to have anything to do with stars. It was destroying their whole suckler scheme, quality cows, weanlings and the whole lot, so farmers just did not do it. I was one of the men who stood up here in this room and said that we did not want Bord Bia or the ICBF involved in the scheme. We wanted an incentive so that farmers could draw down €200 or €250 a cow. Other things could have been involved, not getting involved with the ICBF or Bord Bia. Bord Bia makes no difference to me or to a lot of farmers selling weanlings. My family and I are buying weanlings all over the country every day of the week. If I see a good weanling, it does not matter if it has two stars, three stars or one star.
Five-star animals do not get more than a four-star animal from somebody else.
A no-star animal would get far more money. That is the problem with the schemes.

The other question the Deputy asked about is food security and food health. As Deputy Kenny knows, I was at the night below in Kerry and I said that food security is a serious issue. We can all talk about it but if we get rid of farmers, we are depending on Brazilian beef coming in with carcinogenic hormones that will kill half of Europe with cancer.

That is the big thing about this whole issue. Food security is a serious issue. People do not realise it. Young people are walking away from farming. Who is going to produce the food? It will not be me because I will be finished farming in another few years. It is the same for Deputy Aird or anyone else who is here; we will all be finished farming. Who is going to produce the food? That is what we must ask ourselves. We need a good CAP to produce food. One particular company in this country brings in a load of food from Brazil every week and it is going out to hoteliers and others. Where is the Department? Can it not come along and check that food? Can it not get samples of this food? There is no such thing happening. The company that is bringing it in is well known.

It needs to be labelled. We need to know that. It is all food security at the end of the day. That is why we need to fight hard to keep the CAP money. We must have food security. We cannot rely on other countries to bring in our food.
I need to give Senator Collins an opportunity to speak. She has not spoken yet today.
I will be two minutes. I am watching a screen. I am sorry that I was not here at the start. There has been mayhem in the Seanad today with votes and arguments.

First, I thank Mr. McNamara for coming down on Monday night to our Mercosur meeting and for his contribution. I have one question, which is only on the CAP, he need not worry that it is on Mercosur. What specific changes are needed to keep the family farm viable? Would keeping CAP at its current level do it or does something drastic need to change? It is a very broad question, but that is it and then I will be gone.

I thank the Senator for her question. We have to look at the CAP payment but we must also look at another picture. You name it - everyone else is protected in terms of their earnings and the minimum wage but there is no mention of the farmer who may be at €35,000 and has borrowed so much more to live for the year. This has to be settled in such a way where they must be well above the minimum wage. The risk that they are investing in this is unreal.

It is affecting their life, future and family. The cost is a risk. There is no safeguard there. We have a safeguard in place for somebody who drives to work without any investment. The ICSA's thinking is that smaller farmers or big farmers with less income need that support to raise their standard of living. We can have quality food and everything but if they have no quality of life, they are the main spoke in the wheel.

I have a question about Mr. Donnelly's submission. The other farming organisations might give me a brief comment about it. When a CAP is agreed in Brussels, how much consultation is there with farm organisations and to what degree is it listened to by the Department or is it basically civil servants making the decision? In his submission, Mr. Donnelly asked the committee to inform him. I do not know whether we get any more information on the ins and outs of it. Our secretariat might be able to tell us that. For those with past experience of it and for the new organisations, is there input or is the die cast when it brings them in and tells them what it is doing?

To be fair, the then Minister, Deputy McConalogue, did mart tours and went out and listened directly. He deserved credit for that. It was the first time that was done. Maybe I am wrong. The big question after that was what he did with what he heard. It is one thing to listen to someone, it is another to heed the person. Did he actually take heed of what we said? He may have taken heed of some things but he certainly did not take heed of other things. The reason why I put the diagram in is because I want to know how the big chunk of money - the 400-plus billion euro - for the national plan will be formulated. The European Commission is going to work with the Department of agriculture. Will that document be shared in draft form with farm organisations for critique? These are all questions around communication. What will be made available? Where is it going to be made available so we have the facts and can read them? If we read facts then we can provide some input with a mechanism. The question remains as to whether we will be heeded. Our experience has been fairly poor on that in the past.

Mr. Donnelly mentioned the then Minister's whistle-stop tour around the country. I remember being in Sligo one night and only halfway through the tour around the country, decisions had already been made. That had nothing to do with what information was gathered. It was no fault of the then Minister. He did us justice, came around and met people. It is too far advanced by the time we get engagement to ensure we can direct it in such a way that it is farmer-friendly. We have raised this at different stages. As for support, some of the other groups present have representation on the agricultural knowledge and innovation systems, AKIS, and we may have some input into some of this stuff for the first time ever. That will bring about a change. We are part of that. That will give us a bit of encouragement but it is not enough because we are working off templates that have already been designed.
What is the name of that group?

It is another group where one can get representation on the different bodies of the workings within the Department. We can put different offers forward. At the last meeting, it spoke about doing what it did before on beef. Now it is talking about sheep, sucklers and tillage. Some people are knocking that. We will not name them but the farming bodies wanted them discussed so the farming bodies were heard. The next meeting will be about sheep while the next one will probably be about tillage. It gives us an input into where we see it going forward or where it is being taken that they can bring it back to the different relevant bodies within the Department. It is a big advantage. It is a help. It is not a full open door but it is a starting point. We have to keep opening those doors to get in there but a lot of this is preset at an early stage and we have to try to get that changed.

From having sat through the last CAP consultation committee for the current programme, the initial Commission draft does not really change significantly. The Council of Ministers will come with its approach and the European Parliament, which has co-decision, will have an opportunity to make amendments to the draft text. The Deputy asked whether they just come back and tell members of the CAP consultative committee what is happening. There is an opportunity there to make changes to the legal text through the trilogues right through until there is an agreement between those three groups, namely, the Parliament, the Commission and the Council.

It is critically important that we look from an Irish perspective. I have already said that it is a very divisive draft regulation that for the first time looks at a digressive payment. This regulation was written for the 27 member states, not for Ireland alone. It is a draft document for all member states. Ireland was unique because it had a derogation from the regulation with regard to historic payments. From Paul Savage's contribution here a month ago, it appears that there has been a move away from the entitlements to a new digressive area-based income support. That is where there is a big challenge here and that is where the committee could have a role to play to ensure that this digressive payment would start with all farmers, who must all comply with the same conditionality and stewardship in the new one. We all have to comply with the same rules and regulations. The committee could help to ensure that all farmers would get a uniform support under an area-based payment per hectare. That would be the position of the Irish Natura and Hill Farmers Association. However, the regulation allows for differentiating that payment between different types of farmers based on their agricultural activity, which is very worrying. I hope this will be looked at. Ireland definitely needs all farmers to be supported equally and fairly in this process. This is something I hope the committee takes on board.

I apologise; I was tied up with a funeral in Clare earlier. I welcome the witnesses. It is fantastic to see so many here outlining where we had serious concerns to see how we can get over these concerns. In one presentation, it was stated that CAP post 2027 must present stable, accessible and realistic support systems to meet the demands being made and the Government was asked to recognise that it either can commit to supporting the demands being made or the demands cannot and will not be met. We are well aware of farming. We are well aware that there were a lot of family farms in the past and many families were reared on those farms. I come from one myself. There were ten of us in the family and both my mother and father farmed and worked on the farm. We have moved on in life, unfortunately, and times have changed and now we seem to have mostly part-time farmers. Many of those part-time farmers would not survive without an extra job. We are trying to encourage young people to stay on the farm and continue farming. We are finding it hard to do that.

We are well aware of the age of most farmers at present. That has been announced at different conferences over the last number of years. Now is the time to try to encourage those young people to get involved in farming and to stay farming. That is vitally important into the future. We are well aware of the number of jobs created by farming and agriculture in general.
On CAP post 2027, I am sorry I have missed the meeting for the past couple of hours. What is the witnesses take about what I was saying and what will it do for the young farmers going forward?

As we said earlier, the CAP will be a 20% cut which is a big issue but we will have to overcome that. On getting in the young farmers, getting them engaged and the amount of money that has been ring-fenced, we have to look at the support system to do that but we cannot do it without a package for someone to retire or move on and allow them the space to take over. That is the big block. The land block is only the one size and getting smaller. The big thing for farmers, and especially young people, is they need security. What they need is quite different to a middle-aged farmer – they need to borrow money for a house and have credibility from their incomes. We are so controlled by things like disease, schemes and you name it that they do not have that. Consequently, that security net has to be put in there. The payments have to be looked at and increased to a certain level so that it leaves them in a viable position to go forward because unless they have that on an annual basis we are going nowhere with them and we cannot bring them on even though we want to. Part of our purpose here is to bring young farmers with us but we cannot unless we can guarantee they will have something out of CAP – and we have seen the way it has devalued because of depreciation and cuts over the years, so we are 20 years late to be discussing this. We discussed it every time. As I said earlier, we have seen it in the rising price of cattle. If the CAP payment reached the same level in the same jumps then we could talk and encourage young people into it.

You need to start by asking what do young people want. If they are going to remain farming, they need an income comparable to other sectors. The number of opportunities people have coming out of college, secondary school or whatever is a success story for the country. I heard people earlier talking about minimum wage and so on. Minimum wage does not cut it in the context of the level of responsibilities one has running a farm. If you are a farmer in the morning you have responsibility for insurance, payroll, income tax, farm management plans, financing the farm and HR if you have employees. You have to keep up with all the rules and regulations and there is animal husbandry and health and safety. You are responsible for all those things and working 60 or 70 hours a week. Nobody in any other sector will work for the minimum wage and take on those responsibilities. Where is that income going to come from? It either comes from the price in the marketplace, which is being undermined by cheaper, lower quality products coming in from elsewhere or it comes from support. Therefore there are two choices: the price either comes from the marketplace or it comes from supports. The supports are being cut through CAP so it has to come from the marketplace. Therefore the consumer will have to step up to the plate. If they want the standard of food they are demanding they will have to pay for it.

The other thing that needs to be dealt with is the volatility in farm incomes. If I go into any other sector and take a job I can probably tell you within €500 what my income will be in three or five years’ time. In farming I cannot tell you what my income is going to be within €10,000 in six months’ time. How do you expect young people to come into that sector unless we can guarantee either a price from the marketplace or supports in the form of CAP that will deliver an income comparable to other sectors and be able to take the volatility out of it so that someone can make a business plan for their farm for the next ten, 15 or 20 years that they will borrow money based on or secure a mortgage to live on the farm or buy a house locally? These are the things that young people need – the security they need – before they will go into farming. That is why we are looking at the income volatility tool. The Agri-Food Regulator has a part to play in showing the full transparency of the complete food chain from when something leaves the farm gate to when it arrives on a supermarket shelf.

I have a much quicker answer. I think we are not solving the problem because we are not even identifying it. On the idea that we are 20 years trying to encourage young people into farming, I do not believe that we are. We are showing them all the time that food production is no longer valued in Ireland. We are trying to convince them there is a great future in ecotourism, carbon removals, greenways and growing things for Electric Ireland and calling it farming and then we ask them why they do not want to do that as a charity. We have made it very clear that the priority of CAP is climate and environmental concerns and food production is of secondary importance. A lad who wants to farm wants to grow food. Where is that support?
Would Mr. Slevin make a comment on that?
On farming in Clare?
There are a lot of restrictions on farmers in Clare at the moment in relation to what they can or cannot do to land.
We have already discussed designations.
I know. Unfortunately I was late coming in.

The point I made was the fact this environmental stuff was forced upon us. We had compulsory destocking in the 1980s. There was no compensation whatever. Then in the early 2000s we got the designations imposed on us. We are not allowed to do anything. You cannot drive a single post or dig a bit of a drain without contacting the NPWS and getting approval for it. I just made the point about the amount of effort and resources the Department of agriculture and our representatives put into protecting the derogation for the fertiliser, the slurry and all that kind of stuff and not a single bit of compensation for us whatever. A dairy farmer or his neighbour can apply for a grant of €90,000 to store the slurry along with the neighbour next door and I cannot dig a bit of drain to free a bit of water on my land without any compensation whatever. It is all weighted very much towards others. We are out of the game completely. We are not even recognised. Deputy Fitzmaurice asked a question about AKIS and what it meant and I did not get an opportunity to answer him. I was that AKIS meeting. The senior official in the Department said that 40,000 of us should not even be referred to as “farmers” and the term should not even be used for us. That is a senior official in our own Department of agriculture.
And what was he going to call you?
He was going to cut us out of it completely. He did not need us. He wanted our land for nature and for Sitka spruce – that is what he wanted. To allow the milk to flow. It is as simple as that.

Did the Minister for agriculture not say during the summer that it was very difficult to see a future for all the farmers in the west of Ireland? This was in an interview with Michael Fitzmaurice. We were watching it thinking “Dude. Your inside voice”. That is a thing that happened.
It is very disappointing to hear that comment that there is not a future for farmers in the west of Ireland.
Yes.

That is unbelievable. Another thing that is happening in the west is that sons and daughters of landowners, farmers, are finding it impossible to get planning permission and all the more if they are located on a national road which is totally crazy. I am aware of a farmer who has 200 acres whose two sons had to buy sites elsewhere in order to build a house. Otherwise they would not have been able to get a house. He was on a restricted route - a national road. That is desperate altogether. It is very hard to encourage farming when the likes of that is happening.

I thank Deputy Cooney. He has the last word. I need to bring the meeting to a conclusion. I thank everyone. We have had a wide-ranging discussion. There were a number of questions which may have come thick and heavy which witnesses may feel they did not have the opportunity to answer fully. The option is available to them if they want to send on any further points before Friday and the committee will go ahead to make that political contribution before Christmas. The aim is to get that into Brussels as early as possible so they can have the most influence possible on the shape of the CAP as it is going ahead.
Have all farm organisations been met at this stage?

Every farm organisation has had the opportunity to participate. We are making sure there is an opportunity to make written submissions as well if people feel there are other points to be made. We need to receive those this week to give us the opportunity to make our submission to Brussels before Christmas.
Will our submissions go on to Brussels?
Our submission will go in, and it will be informed by the witnesses' submissions.
Our submissions stay with the committee and do not go any further; currently anyway.
That is right. We are making our submission to Brussels. The witnesses' submissions will be on the web as part of our proceedings and the documents associated with the meeting.
The committee's report to the Commission----
We will be making our political contribution before the end of the year.
Will that be on public record as well? Will we be able to see it?
Yes, that will be published. I thank the witnesses for their contributions. They are valued.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 6.01 p.m. until 11 a.m. on Tuesday, 9 December 2025.
